So we're able to go in and work with a small group of children, usually about eight. We're targeting children who aren't  at the extreme end. So those kids tend to get funding for counselling and their families get a lot of Ministry of Social Development funding. But then there are children who I would say are in rough situations and dealing with some extreme issues, but they don't get that funding because they're not extreme enough. So we're able to just come alongside, build up their self-esteem, have some good mentors for them to  and just hang out. So we did science fun at the start of the year. We blew stuff up, hung out, chatted. This term we're playing t-ball with a group of kids, just showing them how sport benefits their lives and giving them an opportunity to learn a new sport. We also hang out some lunchtimes and morning tea just to be another adult in the playground, just encouraging kind behavior, relationship building. And we also have, we try to encourage teachers who sometimes have a really tough job with some of the social aspects. So we've done just hot scones, hot cookies, just turning up and letting them know that the community  of Cambridge appreciate the hard work that they do. So at the moment we have two youth workers in at five hours each, just hanging out there. We'd love to increase that. We'd love to do it throughout all of the primary schools in Cambridge. But at the moment we are working at Leamington and really enjoying our time there. We've also just started  We're going to run a day camp in October this year, the second week of the holidays, where kids can go to Totara Springs Monday to Friday, but not stay the night. text: So I'm going to keep this really short and sweet. So one of the chamber's current advocacy work streams is the review of our township CCTV capability. And with crime escalating in Cambridge and obviously the increasing number of vehicular invasions, the chamber reactivated or pushed to reopen the conversations with the CCTV working group.  So findings revealed that there are several shortfalls and there's a need to further invest in the following areas. A number plate recognition camera in the northern end of town, an additional camera in Leamington, an additional camera on the low bridge and potentially a monitor for the community CCTVs to add to those policing eyes.  We have obviously spoken with Brian and Gary Knighton and we understand that cost to be around about $50,000. So the chamber is looking actively for a variety of sources for the overall objective of keeping our community safe.  The Cambridge Chamber members, I'm not sure if you're aware, but we recently raised $10,000 to provide CCTV live footage access to the Cambridge Police, to which obviously their feedback has been phenomenal in what that tool has been able to add to their toolbox.  And once we're out of lockdown, we'll also be regathering our retail community who are feeling pretty vulnerable for an update around the security of our town and asking those businesses to make a contribution. Now, whether that's a one off contribution or a weekly pledge,  We'll see how that looks. I mean obviously lockdown 2 has had a pretty instant impact and most of the gains that they'd made in the last 12 months have just gone out the back door again. So we know our retailers in particular are doing it pretty hard. It's good to see the sun shining today and however and you know good people out there supporting the businesses today.  We're also aware that the Te Awamutu Community Board has allocated funding for funds for the CCTV investment in their town. And so as such, I am asking the Cambridge Community Board to consider funding or supporting the funding to the tune of $10,000 to help make our streets and township safer.  That's it. text: Well hi everyone. I was meant to just be a cameo with Debbie but it wasn't meant to be the main item but it's more around the welfare way that we've done the welfare and the way the whole response has been this year.  if you're ready just for me to kick on. We know you've had a bit of a busy year already but carry on. Better to be busy than dead, never mind.  So this year was a bit different to last year. Last year, you remember that the whole response to the COVID was a CDEM response. This year, it's been very clear that CDEM have a support role only in this response, and it's primarily DHB  response and we're there to support them. Now the government made it really clear after the last COVID that they have invested millions and millions of dollars for MSD to run the welfare response in this COVID.  in any COVID reoccurrence. So whereas before we were front and center for welfare, now we've been told to stay in our lane, and MSD will take all of the calls, do all the needs assessment, and anything that fell out of their realm of able to help people, they would refer to us. Some say it's a good idea, some say it's not, but whatever it is, that's how we have to work with.  So what happens is people ring the 0800 number, they get a triage, and they either get a top-up of money if they're existing clients, or they have to go through the process of filling in the necessary approvals and assessments, and then they either get a top-up or referred to a food bank.  If there are other things they need like heating and clothing and all that sort of stuff, they can get help there. So we actually haven't had a single referral from MSD to CDEM in the Waikato and especially not in Waipa.  So whereas last time we had a lot of referrals through the Welfare 0800 number, which we are not allowed to activate this year because it's not our response. So that's how it's been held. Maniapoto have a lot of, the area is quite vast, so they have a lot of poor pocketed areas and communities that get  little funding anyway and then when the main employer goes out you know like the there's three big um abattoirs and that down there that you know usually you're getting like fifteen hundred seventeen hundred dollars a week on the chain all of a sudden you're getting the just the basic five hundred for the wage subsidy that makes a big difference to people's to people's weekly income and what they can expend  But in Cambridge, the Salvation Army report, they did 30 food parcels last week, which is a 300% increase on their normal food take, but they didn't think that that was out of the way or nobody was sort of on the take. text: You have a paper in your agenda on the representation review, which has just gone out for consultation. The consultation opened last Friday. As council adopted a Māori ward on the 19th of May, that now makes a representation review compulsory here in Waipā. So what we're looking at as part of this process is how many elected members we have, how many councillors we have, what areas they cover.  whether we have community boards and how many people are on them and the areas they cover as well. So as part of this exercise and review process, we have adopted an initial proposal and that goes out to the public as of last Friday for a month for public consultation. It's just over a month, closes on the 29th of September.  which the councillors will adopt, and then we go out to the public, the community again. And that process, it's got to be open for a month as well. And so that calls for any or all of the councillors to be able to participate in that process. So that's what we're doing.  appeals or objections to the final proposal. And then if we get any of those, the matter goes to the local government commission who make a decision. So it's quite an extended process that we're embarking on. We have got some changes that we are proposing with this representation review. There's a number of them. We are looking at reducing the number of councillors from 13 down to two.  10 general ward plus the Māori ward councillor. Because of the numbers that we have in our district to try and balance the urban and rural with the growing urban, we've had to look at how our rural wards are structured, because we've got to make sure that the councillors represent a similar number of people. So as part of that process, what we have  done is combined the Poronga and Kakapuku wards. So those are the two wards that look to Te Amuru as a service centre. And then on the Cambridge side, we have extended the Maungatoki ward around to include Kaipake. So now all those rural areas around Cambridge  a part of the Maungatoki Ward. In terms of the urban ward boundaries, there was just some minor changes to them to accommodate statistical areas or accommodate future growth. In terms of the boards, community boards, Council's gone out with a very similar structure to what we have now. In terms of Cambridge, the difference will be  that there, in terms of the numbers, there's now only, there's four rather than five elected members in the Cambridge subdivision. And with the Maungatoetoe subdivision, you've now got, that now will cover a bigger area, including Kaipake. And then on the other side of the district, Tamaru has effectively stayed the same.
